title: Chronic Tympanic Membrane Perforation with Mixed Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have a hole in my left eardrum that has been there for a long time, and I have trouble hearing on that side. I had surgery to fix it three years ago, but it didn't work, so I'm here for a second opinion.

problem_summary.laterality: Left ear primarily; bilateral hearing loss noted on testing.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Occasional otalgia, sensation of pressure in the left ear.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Hearing loss in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Second opinion regarding the perforation and hearing loss.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a long-standing TM perforation in the left ear with occasional otalgia and pressure. He reports hearing loss in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: Chronic ear infections in the left ear since childhood. Tympanoplasty performed 3 years ago was unsuccessful.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows slight sensorineural hearing loss (250-1000 Hz) sloping to mild-to-moderately severe. Left ear shows moderate mixed hearing loss (250-3000 Hz) sloping to severe-to-profound, with a significant air-bone gap.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores align with PTA. Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally despite the hearing loss.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear is normal (Type A). Left ear is flat (Type B) with a large ear canal volume, consistent with the reported perforation.

tests.name: Otoscopy/Medical Exam
tests.key_findings: Otorrhea present in the left ear (suctioned by otologist).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a slight to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear and a moderate mixed sloping to severe/profound hearing loss in the left ear. Word recognition remains excellent in both ears. Tympanometry confirms a patent tympanic membrane perforation in the left ear (large volume Type B) and normal middle ear function in the right ear.
counseling_points: You have an active infection (drainage) in the left ear which was suctioned today; please use the prescribed antibiotic drops.
It is critical to keep water out of your left ear to prevent further infection.
If the left ear remains free of infection for 3 months, a repeat tympanoplasty (surgery to repair the eardrum) may be considered.
We recommend an annual hearing test to monitor your hearing levels.
Once medically cleared, we can evaluate you for hearing aids to help with the hearing loss.
notes_for_actor: You have dealt with ear infections since you were a child and are likely frustrated that the surgery 3 years ago did not fix the hole in your eardrum.
You currently feel some pressure and occasional pain in the left ear.
You are seeking a solution but may be cautious about surgery given the previous failure.
